text:
“This is Pawel Pawlikowski,
the writer and director
of “Cold War.”
So this is a scene in Paris.

Our heroes have been
together for a while,

and they’re starting
to drift apart.

Wiktor is doing his best
to kind of communicate

with the locals and fit in,
whereas Zula is bored out
of her head.

And suddenly,
these first chords

of “Rock Around
the Clock” hit.
(SINGING) — 8 o’clock rock.

9, 10, 11 o’clock,
12 o’clock rock.

We’re gonna rock around
the clock tonight.”

“And she gets
carried off by it.

Wiktor doesn’t even notice
that the music’s changed.

This was a scene which
we rehearsed quite a lot

before filming with a great
Italian ballroom dancing
choreographer.

And then, what we
did on the day,

we disrupted everything that
we’d rehearsed and tried

to kind of catch the camera
operator, Ernest Wilczynski,

by surprise and changed
the order of things a bit.

So there’s a kind of feeling
of chaos and unrehearsedness.

So it feels accidental
and yet kind of perfect.

But it was only
perfect in take 13,

let’s say, where suddenly,
all the right extras

came into the shot
at the right time,

the light hit the lens
in a particular way,

and where Joanna was floating
in a kind of dreamlike state

and abandoning herself to
the music and to the light
and to the movement.

(SINGING) We’ll be
right in seventh heaven.

We’re gonna rock around
the clock tonight.
We’re gonna rock — “

“The whole thing was shot in
an abandoned hotel in Lodz.

And we tried to
make it into a space

where you can
film 360 degrees,

and we put lights that
would hit the camera.

They would light little
details of the scene
but also hit the lens.

So it was a kind of mixture
of chaos and control —

controlled chaos — 
to achieve this —
the scene.”
[bottles jangling]
[shattering]
